txt: Conservation jobs should attract higher pay rates to attract and keep talented, knowledgeable and committed people
Threatened indigenous plants should be protected by stronger legal mechanisms
More money and resources must be spent to protect and restore biodiversity and ecosystem services
Introduced species are not inherently good or bad. Their place in our biodiversity depends on the impact of the specific species.
Maori are being included in this plan because there's 1 million hectares of Maori land that needs to be poisoned.
Save our speecies , BAN1080
Biodiversity habitat and climate change response should go hand in hand
Roles and responsibilities in the biodiversity system need to be better defined and communicated
We need a plan to deal with cats in New Zealand.
Healthy functioning nature is a collective good and private landowners should be compensated if they are protecting or restoring biodiversity or ecosystem services
Current commercial monoculture forestry is damaging our environment. Mixed forestry with higher value species should be promoted
DOC has very little support from the general public due to their obsession on poisoning our environment and food chain with 1080.
I am 55 years old or older
Economics and business aren't the problems. Selfishness is.
Research into CRISPR genome editing must be looked at as a potential pest control tool.
Distributed decisions re:land use must account/forecast impact across human, social, natural, production, intellectual & financial metrics

DOC cost per dead possum is about $25, so a $10 bounty gets lots of youngsters into the bush (connections all round) solves several issues.
There needs to be continual shift towards the mindset that outdoor cats have a significant negative impact on native biodiversity
Instead of focusing on protecting flagship species, we should focus on protecting entire ecosystems, which may include those species.

Nature can manage itself. Humans are the cause of all perceived problems. Management is unnecessary. Leave wild places wild.

Deer/pig/trout are excellent food source, we can never get rid of them so control and use as such

Eradicating predators would be more acheivable if less was spent on poison (1080) and public participation encouraged with a bounty system.
The Biodiversity Strategy needs to prioritise conserving our indigenous species
Nature has the right to exist for its own sake, regardless of any benefits we may get from it
Remove limitations placed on public engagement such as legislative barriers and eurocentric concepts of natural heritage to reduce harm.
Seems too vague a statement to have any meaning
We need to recognise the concept of cultural landscapes and the layers of meaning and connections within a landscape. Reverse western values
The clean water issue having farmers both hill country & flat land under the one umbrella is unfair as the situation is entirely different.
Barren farmed landscapes have become a mental health issue. They must have recognisable native vegetation within it.

Many private land owners will protect native biodiversity on their land if they know how to, and are assisted/encouraged
Biodiversity and environmental stewardships are fundamental obligations of landowners.

There should be a scheme for the trapping or shooting of wild / feral rabbits and the sale of their meat.  Far better than poisoning...
Muttonbirding should no longer be allowed. We need to move on from the past and look towards the future of all species.
There needs to be a stronger emphasis on retaining our endemic invertebrate diversity. Without them our fragile ecosystem wouldn't exist.

Architects need to incorporate biodiversity provisions into building design.
Tourism must be managed to protect biodiversity.
Community conservation groups be better supported through more funding, better access to information and minimising paperwork

The wisdom of nature is greater than our own. We have little understanding of what we are doing.
Ownership of water rights should not allow degradation of the resource.

I live in a medium-sized NZ city
Tourists should be charged slightly more for seeing e.g. a kiwi, than a NZ citizen, and that extra money should go towards conservation.

Whether they live in a city or in a rural area, every New Zealanders opinion matters.

More great advertising like this video with a call to specific action - tell Kiwis what we need to do to help protect our vulnerable species

Farming monocultures are harmful, funding should be given to research and promote diverse  systems of farming.
When NZ species are clearly doomed due to climate crisis, we must stop pest control - this will be pointless, so inhumane.

I don't believe any level of Govt have moral ground for deciding this, as they have all allowed this to happen in the first place

Government should ensure that all riparian protected areas that is manages are fenced from stock damage to vegetation and water quality
